column4: How can I rescue files from a bad hard drive on the Ubuntu Live CD? In all the guides about it there's either a "Computer" icon on Nautilus, or a "Devices" list, and then you can find your hard drive from there, but that's not true for me.
what exactly is not true for you?

On the side of Nautilus where bookmarks/Network and things go, there isn't a "Devices" section. There's a Computer section, but not a "Computer" icon anywhere. And no devices show up on the desktop. (I can re-find the guides that want me to use those things if that helps?)

I guess that the guides you use are outdated then (Gnome 2 vs. Gnome 3/Unity).. and I also guess that the 'Computer' section in Nautilus is what you're looking for (I hardly ever use anything smelling of Gnome ;))

Where under Computer? /media and /dev under File System are the only things that seem like they could be it, and they just have empty folders. https://dl.dropbox.com/u/16623407/Screenshot%20from%202012-10-05%2017%3A37%3A20.png
are you sure the device you're looking for is connected, powered, and in working condition?
I'm trying to view the laptop's main hard drive; I can't boot into it (pretty sure it failed) but apparently I'm supposed to still be able to look at it from the live cd?
indicating that the filesystem is trashed
in that case your only chance might be connecting that disk to a working Windows system & running chkdsk on it
I'll try and figure out if I can connect to a Windows system to run chkdsk.
I don't see an NTFS disk there
rule of thumb: for hard disk partitions, you can normally omit indicating the fs type in the mount options; the mount command should be able to figure out the fs type by itself
Thank you! I'll keep that in mind for future mounting.
unless you need write access to an NTFS partition, then you need to tell it to use ntfs-3g, as the old ntfs option only gives you read access
If it's non-ntfs, will I have write access?
yes.. probably only as root, but yes
